label: 姓
本: Early Japanese History c. 40 B.C.-A.D. 1167,  Part B . Princeton University Press . 1937
説明文: An honorary appelation at first given to the Clan Chieftain (Uji-no-kami) by his clansmen (uji-bito ), meaning lord", "chief", "superior", etc. Later developed into a hereditary title held not only by the Clan Chieftain, but by his close relatives as well. Still later it came to be a kind of official post granted by the Sovereign (Tennō ). Finally, in 684 it became a kind of order of nobillity with eight ranks or degrees, as follows: 1. Mahito, 2. Ason, 3. Sukune, 4. Imiki, 5. Michinoshi, 6. Omi, 7. Muraji, 8. Inagi. The hereditary titles mentioned in this book are: Ason, Atae, Fuhito, Agata-nushi, Imiki, Inagi, Kimi, Kishi, Kuni-no-miyatsuko, Michinoshi, Miyatsuko, Muraji, Obito, Omi, Sukune, Sukuri, Tomo-no-miyatsuko, Wake. [氏上、氏人、天皇、真人、朝臣、宿禰、忌寸、道師、臣、連、稲置、朝臣、直、史、県主、忌寸、稲置、君、吉士、国造、道師、造、連、首、臣、宿禰、村主、伴造、和気]"
